text: only leaders that can govern with an
inclusive agenda are going to be able to
truly bring the Iraqi people together
spurred on by a sense of us support
Iraqi politicians have begun to position
themselves as possible replacements for
embattled prime minister nuri al-maliki
so far these are the ones to watch now
on the New York Times minute there's
four contenders all of whom like Maliki
are members of Iraqis shiite-majority a
leading candidate is Adele Abdul Mahdi
he was within a single vote of being
Prime Minister himself in 2006 he's
known as a moderate with the secular
streak who also works well with the
Kurds an economist by training he served
as finance minister and was a key player
in getting arax debt forgiven in 2004
next is by n Jabbar a former Minister of
the Interior and of Finance he's a
member of the Islamic Revolution of Iraq
one of the most pro-iranian parties in
the country and is seen as a more
divisive choice than mr. Mahdi as
interior minister he allegedly allowed
abuse and torture of mostly Sunni
prisoners a third option is Ibrahim
al-jaafari he's already then Prime
Minister once he's remembered mostly for
his failure in the face of insurgent
violence partly a good resume point with
the new threat from Isis finally there's
Achmed Chalabi in 1998 he helped make
regime change official US policy towards
Iraq but he lost the trust of us
policymakers after the invasion today
his biggest liability could be his
staunch 2003 support addie pacification
that policy is one root of today's
sectarian strife
